Causal Inference in Epidemiology

PhD-Level Course on Causal Inference in Epidemiology

A comprehensive tutorial series on advanced causal inference methods

Course Overview

Welcome to this comprehensive PhD-level tutorial series on causal inference in epidemiology. This course provides a structured approach to understanding and applying causal inference methods in epidemiological research, covering theoretical foundations, methodological approaches, practical applications, and interactive programming exercises.

Causal inference represents one of the most fundamental and challenging aspects of epidemiological research. This tutorial series goes beyond association studies to explore how researchers can make valid causal claims from observational data, incorporate experimental designs, and address the complex issues of confounding, selection bias, and measurement error that complicate causal analyses.

What You'll Learn

Theoretical Framework

  • Philosophical foundations of causality
  • Counterfactual theory and potential outcomes
  • Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
  • Structural equation models

Methodological Approaches

  • Experimental designs
  • Quasi-experimental methods
  • Propensity score methods
  • Inverse probability weighting
  • G-methods and mediation analysis

Practical Applications

  • Infectious disease epidemiology
  • Chronic disease research
  • Environmental epidemiology
  • Social epidemiology
  • Pharmacoepidemiology

Interactive Elements

  • R programming laboratories
  • Interactive DAG builder exercises
  • Simulation workshops
  • Data analysis projects
  • Peer review activities

Target Audience

This tutorial series is designed primarily for:

  • PhD students in epidemiology, biostatistics, or related health sciences
  • Postdoctoral researchers focusing on methods development or application
  • Academic researchers transitioning to causal inference methods
  • Applied epidemiologists in public health agencies seeking advanced methodological training
  • Biostatisticians working in healthcare research

While the content is designed at the PhD level, motivated master's students with strong statistical backgrounds or professionals with substantial research experience may also benefit from these materials.

Prerequisites

To get the most out of this tutorial series, participants should have:

  • Strong foundation in epidemiological methods
  • Intermediate to advanced statistical knowledge
  • Basic programming skills in R
  • Understanding of regression analysis and study design
  • Familiarity with concepts of bias, confounding, and effect modification

Note: While this course focuses on the application of causal inference methods in epidemiology, the principles and techniques are broadly applicable to other fields conducting observational research, including economics, sociology, psychology, and educational research.

Technical Requirements

To complete the practical exercises in this tutorial series, you will need:

  • R and RStudio with required packages (detailed installation instructions provided)
  • Web browser for interactive tools
  • Access to computing resources for simulation and data analysis
  • Recommended: Python (optional, for certain advanced applications)

How to Use This Tutorial Series

This tutorial series is organized into modules that build upon each other. We recommend following this learning pathway:

  1. Begin with the Course Outline to understand the structure and content
  2. Progress through the theoretical foundations before moving to methodological approaches
  3. Complete the practical exercises and coding laboratories that accompany each section
  4. Apply your knowledge to the case studies in the practical applications module
  5. Use the comprehensive bibliography and supplementary resources for deeper exploration
